scenes.name: Down the Rabbit Hole
scenes.summary: Alice spots a hurried rabbit and follows it down a deep rabbit hole, beginning her adventures.
scenes.firstLine: Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do.
scenes.lastLine: In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.

sentiment.quote: what is the use of a book, thought Alice, without pictures or conversation?
Oh dear! Oh dear! I shall be late!

scenes.name: The Pool of Tears
scenes.summary: After growing too large and then too small, Alice cries a pool of tears which she later falls into.
scenes.firstLine: The rabbit-hole went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down.
scenes.lastLine: I wish I hadn't cried so much!

sentiment.quote: I wish I hadn't cried so much!

scenes.name: A Caucus-Race and a Long Tale
scenes.summary: Alice encounters various creatures who have also been affected by the pool of tears, and they participate in a Caucus-Race to get dry.
scenes.firstLine: The first question was, how to get dry again.
scenes.lastLine: 'I shall do nothing of the sort,' said the Mouse, getting up and walking away.

sentiment.quote: Oh, I beg your pardon!
'I shall do nothing of the sort,' said the Mouse, getting up and walking away.
'The best thing to get us dry would be a Caucus-race.'

scenes.name: The Rabbit Sends in a Little Bill
scenes.summary: Alice enters the White Rabbit's house, grows too large, and causes chaos.
scenes.firstLine: It was the White Rabbit, trotting slowly back again, and looking anxiously about as it went, as if it had lost something.
scenes.lastLine: 'And yet what a dear little puppy it was!' said Alice.

sentiment.quote: 'Oh dear, what nonsense I'm talking!'
'Oh my ears and whiskers, how late it's getting!'

scenes.name: Advice from a Caterpillar
scenes.summary: Alice meets a caterpillar who gives her advice on changing size and tells her about the mushroom.
scenes.firstLine: The Caterpillar and Alice looked at each other for some time in silence.
scenes.lastLine: 'One side will make you grow taller, and the other side will make you grow shorter.'

sentiment.quote: 'Who are _you_?' said the Caterpillar.
'Keep your temper,' said the Caterpillar.

scenes.name: Pig and Pepper
scenes.summary: Alice witnesses the chaos at the Duchess's house, including a baby turning into a pig.
scenes.firstLine: For a minute or two she stood looking at the house, and wondering what to do next.
scenes.lastLine: 'If it had grown up,' she said to herself, 'it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes rather a handsome pig, I think.'

sentiment.quote: 'If it had grown up,' she said to herself, 'it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes rather a handsome pig, I think.'
The Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in the middle, nursing a baby; the cook was leaning over the fire, stirring a large cauldron which seemed to be full of soup.
'It's a Cheshire cat,' said the Duchess, 'and that's why. Pig!'
and the baby was howling so much already, that it was quite impossible to say whether the blows hurt it or not.

scenes.name: A Mad Tea-Party
scenes.summary: Alice encounters the Mad Hatter, the March Hare, and the Dormouse, who are having a never-ending tea party.
scenes.firstLine: There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it.
scenes.lastLine: 'At any rate I'll never go _there_ again!' said Alice as she picked her way through the wood.

sentiment.quote: 'This is the stupidest tea party I've ever been to in all my life!'
'Why is a raven like a writing-desk?'
'Have some wine,' the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.
'I wasn't asleep,' he said in a hoarse, feeble voice: 'I heard every word you fellows were saying.'

scenes.name: The Queen's Croquet Ground
scenes.summary: Alice is introduced to the Queen of Hearts and participates in a croquet game with living equipment.

sentiment.quote: 'It's—it's a very fine day!' said Alice.
'Off with his head!'
'Consider, my dear: she is only a child!'

scenes.name: The Mock Turtle's Story
scenes.summary: Alice meets the Mock Turtle and the Gryphon, who share stories about their education under the sea.
scenes.firstLine: 'Come on, then,' said the Queen, 'and he shall tell you his history,'
scenes.lastLine: 'That's the reason they're called lessons,' the Gryphon remarked: 'because they lessen from day to day.'

sentiment.quote: And how many hours a day did you do lessons?' said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.
'When we were little,' the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, 'we went to school in the sea.'
'That's the reason they're called lessons,' the Gryphon remarked: 'because they lessen from day to day.'

scenes.name: The Lobster Quadrille
scenes.summary: The Mock Turtle and Gryphon perform a dance for Alice, leading into a whimsical explanation of a sea dance.
scenes.firstLine: The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes.
scenes.lastLine: 'Thank you, it's a very interesting dance to watch,' said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last.

sentiment.quote: 'Thank you, it's a very interesting dance to watch,' said Alice, feeling very glad that it was over at last.
'You may not have lived much under the sea—' ('I haven't,' said Alice)—'and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster—' (Alice began to say 'I once tasted—' but checked herself hastily).
'Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance?'

scenes.name: Who Stole the Tarts?
scenes.summary: Alice attends a trial where the Knave of Hearts is accused of stealing the Queen's tarts.
scenes.firstLine: The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them.
scenes.lastLine: 'Call the first witness,' said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet.

sentiment.quote: Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there.
'Silence!' screamed the Queen. 'Off with his head! Off—'

'—and just take his head off outside,' the Queen added to one of the officers: but the White Rabbit interrupted, 'Unimportant, your Majesty means, of course,' he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.'
The Knave shook his head sadly. 'Do I look like it?' he said. (Which he certainly did NOT, being made entirely of cardboard.)

scenes.name: Alice's Evidence
scenes.summary: Alice is called to the stand at the trial, but her growing confusion and size disrupt the proceedings.
scenes.firstLine: 'Here!' cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes.
scenes.lastLine: 'Who cares for you?' said Alice, (she had grown to her full size by this time.) 'You're nothing but a pack of cards!'

sentiment.quote: 'Who cares for you?' said Alice, 'You're nothing but a pack of cards!'
'Silence!' screamed the Queen.
'Consider your verdict,' the King said to the jury.
The jury all wrote down on their slates, 'She doesn't believe there's an atom of meaning in it.'

locations.name: The Rabbit Hole
locations.quote: In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.

locations.name: The Pool of Tears
locations.quote: However, she soon made out that she was in the pool of tears which she had wept when she was nine feet high.

locations.name: The Garden
locations.quote: Alice opened the door and found that it led into a small passage, not much larger than a rat-hole: she knelt down and looked along the passage into the loveliest garden you ever saw.

locations.name: The Duchess's Kitchen
locations.quote: The door led right into a large kitchen, which was full of smoke from one end to the other: the Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in the middle, nursing a baby.

locations.name: The March Hare's House
locations.quote: There was a table set out under a tree in front of the house, and the March Hare and the Hatter were having tea at it.

locations.name: The Queen's Croquet Ground
locations.quote: The Queen's Croquet-Ground was a very curious sight.

characters.quote: Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do.
suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.
'Mine is a long and sad tale!' said the Mouse.
'The best way to explain it is to do it.'
'If it had grown up,' she said to herself, 'it would have made a dreadfully ugly child: but it makes rather a handsome pig, I think.'
The Duchess was sitting on a three-legged stool in the middle, nursing a baby.
'It's a Cheshire cat,' said the Duchess, 'and that's why. Pig!'
'Have some wine,' the March Hare said in an encouraging tone.
'Your hair wants cutting,' said the Hatter.
'I wasn't asleep,' he said in a hoarse, feeble voice: 'I heard every word you fellows were saying.'
'Off with his head!' she said, without even looking round.
'Consider my dear: she is only a child!' the King said.
'Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance?'
'When we were little,' the Mock Turtle went on at last, more calmly, though still sobbing a little now and then, 'we went to school in the sea.'
'I haven't done anything wrong,' said the Knave of Hearts, 'and I don't deserve to be punished.'
The jury all wrote down on their slates, 'She doesn't believe there's an atom of meaning in it.'
